title-group.article-title: Severe ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow: functional outcome after minimally invasive in situ decompression

abstract.p: The role of in situ decompression in patients with severe ulnar nerve compression is still controversial. Thirty patients with severe ulnar nerve compression confirmed clinically and electrophysiologically underwent simple decompression. The mean age of the patients was 58 (range 26–87) years. Through incisions ≤4 cm the nerves were fully visualized and decompressed. Outcome was measured prospectively using Modified Bishop’s score (BS), grip and pinch strengths and two-point discrimination (2PD). Significant improvement in power (p = 0.01) and pinch grip (p = 0.001) was noted at 1 year. The grip strength continued to improve up to 1 year. According to the BS, 24 patients (80%) had good to excellent results at 1 year. Minimally invasive in situ decompression is technically simple, safe and gives good results in patients with severe nerve compression. The BS and 2PD were more reliable than grip strength in assessing these patients at follow-up.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ulnar nerve entrapment in the cubital tunnel is the second-most common peripheral entrapment neuropathy (Szabo and Kwak, 2007). Surgical treatment includes simple decompression, and decompression with medial epicondylectomy, or subcutaneous or submuscular anterior transposition of the nerve. Though in situ decompression of the ulnar nerve has been shown to produce results equivalent to more complex procedures in patients with mild and moderate compression, its role in severe compression is still controversial (Bartels et al., 1998; Biggs and Curtis, 2006; Mowlavi et al., 2000; Waugh and Zlotolow, 2007). A meta-analysis to identify the effectiveness of various methods of treatment for ulnar nerve compression found that no particular method was more effective in treating patients with severe compression (Mowlavi et al., 2000).

Simple decompression is typically performed via a posteromedial incision around 6–8 cm long (Waugh and Zlotolow, 2007). Some authors have suggested the use of an endoscope to decompress the ulnar nerve via a smaller incision (1.5–4 cm) (Hoffman and Siemionow, 2006; Yoshida et al., 2009). The advantages claimed for endoscopic decompression are limited tissue dissection, reduced pain following surgery and a more rapid return to work (Yoshida et al., 2009). However, the endoscopic release is a technically demanding operation, with a longer operating time and higher surgical costs.
We describe a prospective cohort study of a minimally invasive approach to ulnar nerve decompression in patients with severe ulnar neuropathy.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: This prospective study included 46 patients who underwent surgery between January 2006 and December 2008 (Figure 1). All the patients had clinical and neurophysiologic confirmation of cubital tunnel syndrome. Strict inclusion and exclusion criteria (Figure 1) were followed and all the patients had conservative treatment for an average of six (range 4–12) weeks. Dellon’s classification (Table 1) was used to classify the severity of nerve compression (Dellon, 1989). Patients with severe symptoms (30 patients) were included in the study and their results evaluated.

sec.p: Preoperative grip strength was measured clinically with a Jamar dynamometer and pinch grip was measured using Jamar hydraulic pinch gauge. All patients underwent minimally invasive in situ decompression as a day-case procedure.

sec.title: Surgical technique
sec.p: The surgery was performed under brachial plexus block or general anaesthesia. A pneumatic tourniquet was used. The shoulder was positioned in 90° of forward flexion and 70–90° of internal rotation withelbow in 90° of flexion (Figure 2). The assistantstanding on the opposite side held the forearmstable. The ulnar nerve was palpated and a 3 cm longitudinal incision was made, starting froma point midway between the medial epicondyle and olecranon process and extending distally parallel to the medial border of ulna. The arcuate ligamentwas exposed by blunt dissection and released under direct vision (Figure 3). The aponeurotic fasciaof the flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) was split protecting the motor branches to the FCU. The mobility ofthe skin was utilized to release the nerve by splitting the superficial fascia over FCU to allow access of the surgeon’s little finger to feel along the nerve(Figure 4) to exclude entrapment within the muscle or by the deep fascia of FCU (Al-Qattan and Duerksen, 1992; Siemienow et al., 2007). After distal release, the elbow was extended and the skin retracted so that the nerve was decompressed proximally under direct vision (Figure 5). This identifies any entrapment by an accessory anconeus muscle, fibrous adhesions or scarring around the point of the elbow or any ligamentous or fascial bands causing compression proximally. The tourniquet was then released to inspect the nerve to record that it blushes pink and appears well vascularized confirming an adequate release. If the nerve remained white then the plan would be to extend the incision to perform a radical release under magnification. This was never needed during performance of the study series. The wound was closed with non-absorbable sutures to the skin only.

The tight ligament over the nerve was released under direct vision.
The nerve was palpated by the surgeon’s little finger, to ensure the complete release of the nerve distally.
The elbow was extended and the skin retracted on either side of the nerve, so that the nerve was decompressed proximally under direct vision.

sec.title: Assessment
sec.p: Patients were followed up clinically and the results were evaluated in accordance with the Modified Bishop’s scoring system (BS) (Kleinman and Bishop, 1989; Nouhan and Kleinert, 1997) (Figure 6). We also measured grip strength, using a Jamar dynamometer, and two-point discrimination (2PD) at 3 months and 1 year postoperatively. The results were classified as poor (if the score was 0–2), fair (3–4), good (5–7) and excellent (8–9).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS software (version 16.0, Chicago, Illinois). Data were tested for normality using Shapiro–Wilk’s test. If normally distributed (parametric) the data was compared using paired t-tests. Non-normal (non-parametric) data was analysed using the Wilcoxon Signed Rank Test. A p-value of 0.05 or less was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 20 men and 10 women with a mean age of 58 (range: 26–87) years with 43% (13/30) of cases involving the dominant hand. The mean operating time was 13 (range 10–17) minutes with minimal blood loss in all cases. Intraoperatively a tight arcuate ligament was identified in all the patients and was released. At follow-up there were no tender scars or sign of neuroma formation/sensory changes related to cutaneous sensory nerve supply. A statistically significant difference in pinch grip scores was observed at 3 months (p = 0.04) and for both pinch grip (p = 0.001) and grip strength (p = 0.01) at 12 months following surgery (Table 2).

fn.p: SD: standard deviation; SE: standard error of mean; CI: confidence interval.

sec.p: According to the Modified Bishop’s scoring (BS) (Table 3), 24 patients (80%) had good to excellent results at 1 year. Of the eight patients with fair results at 3 months, four improved further while two deteriorated, leading to a total of four poor results (13.3%) at 1 year. Of the two patients who had deteriorated, one had developed cervical disc disease at 8 months after surgery and the other a flexor sheath infection in the hand at 10 months after surgery. In the two other patients with poor results, at 3 months and 1 year, both had no change in neurology at 1 year but reported relief of their preoperative pain. Surprisingly, all four patients with poor results were happy with the outcome of the surgery and refused further investigations and treatment. The two patients with fair results (6.7%) were both unemployed and living on benefits. Though they showed an improvement in grip power and two-point discrimination their BS remained the same.

caption.p: Modified Bishop’s score and two-point discrimination

sec.p: Two-point discrimination (2PD) showed improvement at both 3 months and 1 year with an improving BS (Table 3). All the patients with poor results had 2PD more than 6 mm at 1 year follow-up. No complications or recurrence of compressive symptoms were noted in our patients.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The surgical treatment of severe ulnar nerve compression at the elbow is still controversial. No particular technique has been shown to give consistently superior results. Various different techniques are claimed to give better results when compared with another technique in each of these published studies: Mowlavi et al., 2000; Waugh and Zlotolow, 2007; Macadam et al., 2008; Gervasio et al., 2005.

Data from cadaveric studies has shown that the intraneural pressure increases in a normal ulnar nerve when the elbow is flexed (Dellon et al., 1994; Gelberman et al., 1998) and that this change in intraneural pressure remains the same even after the release of Osborne’s ligament (Gelberman et al., 1998). These studies concluded that traction was the main cause for ulnar nerve compression symptoms and suggested the nerve should either be transposed or decompressed by a medial epicondylectomy (Dellon et al., 1994; Gelberman et al., 1998). What has not been shown in these studies is that the observed level of intraneural pressure is responsible for nerve dysfunction clinically. Also, the data showed that a normal ulnar nerve experiences an increase in intraneural pressure that is independent of any external compression on flexion. Waugh and Zlotolow (2007) suggested that if the causative factor for cubital tunnel syndrome is traction then the nerve can be elongated by stretching rather than by subjecting the patient to surgery. Mowlavi et al. (2000) in their meta-analysis observed that transposition of the ulnar nerve after previous medial epicondylectomy has a poorer outcome in patients with severe symptoms. This further emphasizes the fact that compression is the main cause of symptoms rather than traction.

Congenital laxity of the cubital tunnel retinaculum with resultant ulnar nerve hypermobility has also been suggested as a cause for compression neuropathy (Posner, 1998). He postulated that friction over the medial epicondyle might cause inflammation on the nerve leading to increased pressure. Also, a more superficial location than normal may make it more prone to injury (Polatsch et al., 2007). The above mentioned theories are questionable as in approximately 20% of the population this condition is often bilateral and asymptomatic (Childress, 1975). In patients with bony deformities, unlike idiopathic compression, the nerve experiences compression, traction and instability due to the altered anatomy around the nerve leading to the nerve being prone to compression in multiple sites around the elbow (Abe et al., 1995; Ogino et al., 1986). Such patients were excluded from this study (Figure 1).

Many studies (Chung, 2008; Mowlavi et al., 2000; Nouhan and Kleinert, 1997) have advocated anterior submuscular transposition of the ulnar nerve in patients with severe compression. This is an extensive procedure with complications related to neuromas of the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve, CRPS, loss of movement at the elbow and rupture of the pronator–flexor mass (Nouhan and Kleinert, 1997; Pasque and Rayan, 1995). Manipulation of the nerve (extensive handling or retraction) may create new sites of compression due to scar formation and potentially the nerve may encounter new constrictive bands in their transposed site (Chung, 2008). Mobilization of the nerve for transposition can devascularize the nerve and cause intractable nerve pain with worsening of motor and sensory symptoms (Campbell et al., 1974; Lim et al., 1992). In contrast a simple in situ decompression preserves the vital blood supply to the nerve with a reduced operating time and preservation of the anatomic location of the nerve (Zlowodzki et al., 2007). The above mentioned complications that are known to occur in anterior transposition are not reported in simple decompression.

Another advantage of simple in situ decompression is a shorter postoperative recovery time, and early rehabilitation and return to work. A cost-minimization analysis by Bartels et al. (2005) showed that simple decompression is more cost effective than anterior transposition.

Gervasio et al. (2005) in a prospective randomized study on patients with severe ulnar nerve entrapment found no difference in functional outcome between simple decompression and transposition. A meta-analysis by Zlowodzki et al. (2007) and a decision-making analysis paper by Brauer and Graham (2007) have recommended simple in situ release of the ulnar nerve, even in patients with severe symptoms. We therefore wished to evaluate our results of a minimally invasive approach to an in situ decompression of the severely compressed ulnar nerve in the cubital tunnel.

The principle of a minimally invasive approach is similar to an in situ decompression, where the nerve is completely decompressed, but through a smaller incision. The handling of the nerve and surrounding tissue dissection is kept to a minimum. The minimally invasive technique can be converted to other techniques. A recent study by Goldfarb et al. (2009) showed that the in situ decompression leads to improvement in patients with persistent or worsening of the symptoms and the reoperation rate is about 7%. This further supports our view that the patients with severe nerve compression can have simple decompression initially and the more extensive surgical procedures can be tried in resistant cases.

The role of endoscopic decompression in cubital tunnel syndrome is unclear. The principle is similar to in situ decompression but has a steeper learning curve, a longer operative time and increased cost (Hoffman and Siemionow, 2006; Yoshida et al., 2009). Our technique has the advantages of reduced tissue morbidity and early rehabilitation but without the above limitations of endoscopic decompression.

Macadam et al. (2009) in a recent meta-analysis identified a significant gap in the literature in assessing these patients after surgical decompression. They stated that a consistent method of evaluating patients before and after surgery is missing in most of the current studies (Macadam et al., 2009). In our study, we assessed all the patients subjectively (for pain and paraesthesia), objectively (2PD and grip and pinch strength) and used the BS as suggested by the meta-analysis (Macadam et al., 2009). Though there is contrasting evidence regarding the use of 2PD for assessment of nerve recovery (Lundborg and Rosen, 2004; Shooter, 2005), we found that the two-point discrimination is more reliable than grip strength and demonstrated consistent improvement after a successful decompression. This correlated with the improvement of subjective symptoms and an improved BS. In contrast the change in the grip strength at 3 months did not keep up the pace with the improvement of subjective symptoms and 2PD in the patients but showed better correlation to improvement at 1 year.

We conclude that 2PD is a simple and consistent predictor in assessing outcome and mini-open in situ decompression is technically a simple and safe procedure that can be performed for patients with severe cubital tunnel syndrome.
